Gold holds its year-end momentum as miners hit records and geopolitics boost metal demand

Gold remains resilient into year-end, trading in a tight but elevated range. Record highs in leading miners, growing state-level interest in tokenization, and steady ETF flows all reinforce the metalâ€™s role as a strategic asset going into 2026.

Market trends
â€¢ Geopolitical driver: governments deepen their exploration of blockchain and tokenization. Pakistan is in talks with Binance to tokenize up to $2B in state assets, potentially tying gold more directly into digital public-finance rails.
â€¢ ETF demand: issuance of gold ETCs remains active. Xtrackers added 65,000 new units, while Amundi placed several fresh tranches last week, signaling ongoing institutional demand.
â€¢ Macro backdrop: expectations of slower growth in India and a weaker rupee into 2026 could support local gold buying as a store of value.

Techs
Support: $4,250â€“4,300 (current consolidation zone)
Resistance: $4,450â€“4,500 (a breakout opens room toward $4,600)

Equities
Gold miners continue to rip higher, with multiple majors printing fresh highs as strategic deals close and balance sheets strengthen.
â€¢ Record highs:
â€“ Kinross Gold ($28.81)
â€“ Barrick Mining ($43.10)
â€“ Newmont Goldcorp ($98.75)
â€“ Wheaton Precious Metals ($114.49)
These levels reflect strong confidence in sustained margins and cash flows.
â€¢ Deals & funding:
â€“ Aris Mining completes its acquisition of the remaining 49 percent of Soto Norte, fully consolidating a key asset.
â€“ Gold Royalty closes a $103.5M equity raise; Scotiabank lifts its target to $5.00.
â€“ Streamex acquires 9.9 percent of Empress Royalty via share exchange, deepening its royalty exposure.
â€¢ Other developments:
â€“ The Tahltan Nation approves an agreement on the Eskay Creek project in Canada, reducing permitting risk and clearing the way for development.
â€“ VCI Global shuts down a credit facility to shift focus toward digital-asset opportunities.

Crypto vs Gold
Tension between crypto narratives and real-asset cash flows sharpens.
â€¢ Bitcoin: Peter Schiff escalates his criticism, comparing Michael Saylor to Sam Bankman-Fried, underscoring rising doubts about the sustainability of highly leveraged BTC strategies.
â€¢ Gold: continues to strengthen its position through blockchain integration. Pakistanâ€™s tokenization plans highlight goldâ€™s role as high-quality collateral in a digital context. Record highs in Newmont and Barrick underline that this sector is built on operating mines and cash flow rather than purely on sentiment.
Takeaway: while crypto battles reputational and governance issues, the gold sector showcases corporate maturity and operational resilience at record price levels.

What to watch
â€¢ Year-end inflation and retail-sales data in major economies.
â€¢ Central-bank commentary from the Fed and peers as they wrap up 2025.
â€¢ Goldâ€™s ability to hold above $4,300 and whether miners can defend recent gains.
â€¢ Further announcements on state-level tokenization initiatives using gold as collateral.

Takeaways
â€¢ Gold: holding above $4,250 into year-end sets a constructive tone for 2026. The $4,250â€“4,300 band acts as support, with $4,500 still a realistic target for Q1 if macro conditions donâ€™t deteriorate. Geopolitical interest in gold-backed tokenization is emerging as a new structural driver.
â€¢ Miners: record highs in leading producers and royalty names reflect a re-rating of the sector. A selective approach is key: focus on companies with strong balance sheets, disciplined capital allocation, and credible dividend or royalty profiles (Newmont, Barrick, Wheaton, quality royalty players).
â€¢ Crypto: extreme caution remains warranted. Intensifying criticism from figures like Schiff raise reputational and structural risks, making gold the safer choice for conservative capital.

Not financial advice. Always do your own research.
